sentences.sentence: She then spoke of the letter, repeating all that it said about George Wickham.
How this upset poor Jane!
She would willingly have gone through the world without believing that so much wickedness( 不道德 ) existed in the whole of mankind, as was here collected in one man.
She tried to prove that some mistake had been made, and neither of the two men was as bad as they had at first believed.
“This will not do,” said Elizabeth.
“There is only enough goodness between them to make one good man, and recently that goodness has been moving about between them pretty much.
For my part, I believe that the good is all Darcy’s, but you shall do as you choose.”
“I do not know when I have been more shocked,” said Jane.
“Wickham so very bad!
There is such an expression of goodness in his face!
Such an openness and gentleness in his manner! It is almost beyond belief.
And poor Mr. Darcy!
Dear Lizzy, only consider what he must have suffered.”
“And yet I meant to be uncommonly clever in taking such a dislike to Mr. Darcy, without any reason.
There certainly was some great mismanagement( 处置失当 ) in the education of those two young men.
One has got all the goodness, and the other all the appearance of it.”
“There is one point on which I want your advice,” Elizabeth continued.
“Do you think I ought to explain Wickham’s character to our acquaintances( 熟人 ) in general?”
Miss Bennet paused a little, and then replied, “Surely there can be no reason to expose( 揭露 ) him so dreadfully( 糟糕地 ).
What do you think?”
“I agree.
Mr. Darcy has not authorized( 准许 ) me to make his communication public—
in fact, he was very clear that what he told me about his sister, at least, should never be repeated to anyone.
The general prejudice( 偏见 ) against Mr. Darcy is so violent, that it would be the death of half the good people in Meryton to attempt to place him in an amiable( 和蔼的 ) light.
Wickham will soon be gone.
And after that it will not matter to anyone here what he really is.”
“You are quite right.
To have his errors made public might ruin him forever.
He is now, perhaps, sorry for what he has done, and anxious to save his reputation( 名声 ).
We must not make him desperate( 绝望的 ).”
The first week of their return passed quickly.
The following week was to be the last of the army regiment’s stay in Meryton, and all the young ladies in the neighborhood were distressed( 痛苦的 ).
Only the eldest two Bennet sisters were still able to eat, drink, and sleep, and enjoy themselves as usual.

Very frequently they were criticized( 被批评 ) as insensitive( 反应迟钝的 ) by Kitty and Lydia, who were themselves extremely miserable( 伤心的 ), and who could not understand such a lack of sympathy from anyone in their family.
But Lydia’s mood( 心情 ) soon improved when she received an invitation from Harriet Forster, the wife of the colonel of the regiment( 团 ), to travel with her to Brighton.
This valuable friend was a very young woman, and very recently married.
She and Lydia shared much in common, and of the three months they had known each other, they had been close friends( 朋友 ) for two.
Lydia’s joy at this invitation can barely( 几乎没法 ) be described.
Elizabeth tried to make her act more sensibly( 明智地 ) without success, and Jane also tried and failed to calm her down.
As for Elizabeth herself, she did not share Lydia’s excitement at this invitation, and could not help but secretly urge( 规劝 ) her father not to let her go.
He listened to her attentively( 聚精会神地 ), and then said:
“Lydia will never be at ease until she has embarrassed( 使尴尬 ) herself in some public place or another.
Under the present circumstances( 境遇 ), she will be able to do so with as little inconvenience( 麻烦 ) as possible to her family.”
“If you were aware,” said Elizabeth,
“of how others’ opinion of Lydia’s foolish manner has already disadvantaged us all, I am sure you would think differently about the matter.
Our position and reputation( 名声 ) in society must surely be affected by Lydia’s complete lack of self-control.
Excuse me, but I must speak openly.
If you, my dear father, will not take the trouble to keep her under control, she will, at sixteen, be the most determined flirt( 调情者 ) that ever made herself or her family ridiculous( 荒谬 ).”
Mr. Bennet saw that she was very passionate( 激昂的 ) about this subject, and affectionately taking her hand, he said in reply:
“Do not worry yourself unnecessarily, my love.
Wherever you and Jane are known, you must be respected and valued.
It will not damage your reputation( 名声 ) to have a couple of—or I may say, three—very silly sisters.
We will have no peace at Longbourn if Lydia does not go to Brighton.
Let her go, then.
Colonel Forster is a sensible( 明智的 ) man, and will keep her out of any real trouble.
There are many women at Brighton more worth the officers’ notice than Lydia, so perhaps she may learn at Brighton that she is not as important as she thinks.
She is luckily too poor to be taken advantage of by anybody.”
Had Lydia known what Elizabeth had discussed with her father, what would she have felt?
In Lydia’s imagination, a visit to Brighton would make her the happiest woman in the world.
She imagined herself as being the center of attention to countless admiring gentlemen whom she would soon have the chance to meet.
But Lydia was entirely unaware of what had been said, and she remained filled with excitement until the day she at last left home.
On the very last day before the regiment( 团 ) was to leave, Wickham and some other officers came to dinner at Longbourn.
Wickham asked Elizabeth why she had been away from Meryton for so long, and she replied that she had spent some time in Kent where she had frequently met Mr. Darcy.
“His manners are very different from Mr. Bingley’s,” said Wickham.
“Yes, very different.
But I think Mr. Darcy improves upon acquaintance( 交情 ).”
“Indeed?
Is his manner now somewhat more civil?” asked Wickham, “For I dare not hope that he is improved in essentials( 本质 ).”
“No,” replied Elizabeth, “in essentials( 本质 ), I believe he is very much what he always was.”
Wickham looked doubtfully at her, as if trying to work out whether her words had a hidden meaning.
At the end of the evening they parted with mutual( 双方的 ) civility, and perhaps a mutual( 双方的 ) desire never to meet again.
While Elizabeth was happy that Wickham had gone, she had no other reason for being satisfied that the regiment( 团 ) was gone.
Her mother and sister complained( 抱怨 ) of boredom, while she worried about Lydia in Brighton.
She found what has sometimes been found before—that an event one looks forward to very much does not, when it happens, give one all the happiness one expects,
and so the start of one’s actual happiness has to be postponed( 推迟 ) yet again.
She needed to place her wishes and hopes on some other, later event—in this case, the trip with the Gardiners to the Lake District.

article_info.previous: Elizabeth在得知了真相之后惊讶万分，同时也十分羞愧自己对Mr. Darcy的误解和偏见，但最后还是尽力强行让自己平静了下来。Elizabeth回到了家，犹豫万分，决定把真相告诉Jane，Jane对Mr. Darcy表示了无限的同情和怜惜。
article_info.share_words: She found what has sometimes been found before- that an event one looks forward to very much does not when it happens, give one all the happiness one expects.

question.cn: Elizabeth告诉Jane一切后， Jane是怎么想Mr. Darcy的？
question.en: What did Jane think about Mr. Darcy after Elizabeth told her everything?

options.en: She had a lot of sympathy with Mr. Darcy.
She thought Mr. Darcy was very ridiculous.
She believed Mr. Darcy to be a bad person.

analysis: 文中Jane说到：“And poor Mr. Darcy! Dear Lizzy, only consider what he must have suffered.”所以选A。

question.en: Who did Harriet Forster invite to travel with her to Brighton?

analysis: 文中提到：“But Lydia’s mood soon improved when she received an invitation from Harriet Forster, the wife of the colonel of the regiment, to travel with her to Brighton.” 所以选C。

question.cn: Elizabeth在得知了邀请之后做了什么？
question.en: What did Elizabeth do when she knew about the invitation?

options.en: She encouraged  her sister to go.

options.cn: 她很沮丧因为她没有被邀请。
options.en: She was upset that she was not invited.

options.cn: 她力劝她父亲不要让她妹妹去.。
options.en: She urged her father not to let her sister go.

analysis: 文中提到：“As for Elizabeth herself, she did not share Lydia's excitement at this invitation, and could not help but secretly urge her father not to let her go.” 所以选C。

question.en: Did Lydia go to Brighton finally?

analysis: 文中Mr. Bennet说到：“We will have no peace at Longbourn if Lydia does not go to Brighton. Let her go, then.” 所以选A。

share_title: 100天读完4本英文书，今天是第86天
